page.description: The Xbasic programming language supports 11 types of variables (see Variable Data Types and Scope ). You will find yourself using the following types of variables.

case.title: Type Symbol:
case.description: B

case.title: Values:
case.description: Binary data (e.g. images). Blob data cannot be directly displayed. Browsers can only display image data from a named file.

case.title: Type Symbol:
case.description: C

case.title: Values
case.description: Alpha-numeric characters. A NULL string is represented by "".

case.title: Type Symbol:
case.description: D

case.title: Values
case.description: A date and time between where the date is between 00/00/0000 and 12/31/9999. Your browser can display date values according to your system preference.

case.title: Type Symbol:
case.description: L

case.title: Values
case.description: TRUE (.T.) or FALSE (.F.). Your browser displays these values as "True" and "False".

case.title: Type Symbol:
case.description: N

case.title: Values
case.description: A number of up to 19 digits, or 18 digits when there is a decimal point. Your browser displays decimal numbers with 6 digits after the decimal point.

case.title: Type Symbol:
case.description: P

case.title: Values
case.description: A reference (pointer) to an object, or a pointer to a "dot" variable. Pointers are never displayed.

case.title: Type Symbol:
case.description: T

case.title: Values
case.description: A time value that stores the date, hour, minute, seconds and hundredths of a second. Your browser does not display time values.

section.description: In addition, Alpha Anywhere tables support these field types.
HTML displays most of the common data types without any special formatting or conversions.
Sometimes you will have to convert data types before they will display correctly on an HTML page.

section.title: Assigning and Using Variables
section.description:
When you create a variable with the DIM statement you assign it one of the data types mentioned above. Afterwards, until you delete it and DIM it again, it can store only that data type.
For example, if you have this statement.
The following statement will cause an error.

The cFirstname field cannot store a different data type. This principle applies to all variable types.
If you want to assign a value to cFirstname, you can write the first statement in two different and equivalent ways.
section.example: dim cFirstname as C = "Fred" dim cFirstname as C cFirstname = "Fred"

section.description:
The practical difference is that the first alternative provides a default value for the variable, which might be useful.
The numeric data type support integers and decimal numbers, sometime referred to as floating point, single, or double precision numbers in other programming languages. You do not have to worry about the placement of the decimal point. The following statements are valid.
section.example: dim nSmall as N = 2 dim nBig as N = 12000345 dim nFraction as N = -12.345 dim nVerySmall as N nVerySmall = .000000123

section.description: The date data type contains only the date. The time data type includes both date and time information. When assigning a value to a date variable, you must use curly braces and forward slashes as illustrated below.
When assigning a value to a time variable, you must place quotes around the values.
section.example: dim dt as T dt = "4/15/04 2:12:03 pm"

section.title: Choosing the Correct Data Type
section.description: Choosing the correct data type should be easy if you follow these rules.

case.name: Character
case.description: Consider the character data type to be the default.

case.name: Numeric
case.description: Use numeric variables to work with amounts: anything that might need to be arithmetically processed.

case.name: Logical
case.description: Use logical variables when you want a variable that can be "Yes" or "No", "On" or "Off", or "True" or "False".

case.name: Date
case.description: Use date variables to save date values or to calculate the difference between two dates.

case.name: Time
case.description: Use time variables to save time of day values or to calculate the difference between two time values.

section.title: Adding comments
section.description:
Both HTML and Xbasic allow you to insert comments into a page. In both cases the comments will not appear on the page.
Precede an Xbasic comment with a single quote. Remember that an Xbasic comment has to be inside an Xbasic code block, which is defined by <%a5 and %>.
Surround an HTML comment with <!-- and ->.
Comments are a recommended technique for documenting your applications. They make it easier to go back and maintain previously developed pages and programs.
